awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  ARTS:  Understanding Tropical  Invertebrate Diversity Through Integrative Revisionary  Systematics and Training
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to document the biodiversity of marine organisms of the southern Caribbean and to train the next generation of researchers working on ecologically and economically important, but under-studied marine invertebrates (clams, sea slugs, flatworms, ribbon worms, seed shrimp, and scuds). Conceptually, this project focuses on three major challenges in understanding biodiversity: (1) documenting global biodiversity and its importance to the well-being of the nation, (2) identifying and describing new species, and (3) determining the relationships within and among animal groups. Taxonomy, the science of finding, describing and naming organisms, is vital to all biological research and to understanding and conserving biodiversity. The on-going effort to survey, inventory, and preserve the ocean's biological diversity is threatened by a shortage of taxonomic expertise. This project will train the next generation of young US STEM researchers to become experts who can document biodiversity in these groups of animals, apply novel methods to help resolve the relationships between these groups, and ultimately understand the origins of animal life. This effort will also promote conservation of marine animals, which are economically important, but are poorly documented compared to terrestrial organisms. It will also aid in the detection of invasive species. This project will produce new species descriptions for animals in the focal groups, generate species lists for Panama and the southern Caribbean, and will contribute data to an online biodiversity website and field guide. 

The activities fall into three parts with complementary aims. (1) Taxonomic research will include species descriptions, taxonomic revisions, and development of regional check-lists and keys within the six taxonomic groups. This work will emphasize the integration of conventional morphological and molecular characters with non-traditional characters such as type and morphology of larvae or gametes, novel anatomical details, and 3D imaging. Established experts will work closely with experts-in-training to review and revise these animals from the Caribbean, which are in particular need of taxonomic attention. (2) The project will support six 14-day workshops mixing US and international experts and trainees at the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute tropical field station in Panama. These workshops will train participants in methods for identification, improve understanding of relationships among the groups, provide hands-on experience with tropical diversity, and build lasting international collaborations to promote US biodiversity research and improve accessibility to international field locations. (3) Informatics resources will be developed to make the basic skills and vocabulary involved in taxonomy of the six groups globally accessible to expert and non-specialist workers in biodiversity and conservation. This work will involve the development of a package of online tools for each group, including a set of "how-to" videos, illustrated glossaries of anatomical terms, and checklists and digital keys of local species. This toolkit will be designed to facilitate rapid taxonomic documentation and to increase the precision of field identifications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Most species on Earth remain undescribed. This means we lack the baseline knowledge to understand ecosystem function, monitor response to climate change, and inform conservation priorities, and sustainable use of biodiversity. The shortage of taxonomic expertise relative to the large number of undescribed taxa (taxonomic impediment) is one of the biggest challenges facing researchers engaged in identifying, classifying, and conserving the world's biodiversity. The taxonomic impediment to the study of biodiversity is particularly strong for high-diversity tropical regions and for marine organisms, especially those that are soft-bodied, small, and live hidden in the crevices of complex three-dimensional habitats, such as coral reefs. Marine ribbon worms (phylum Nemertea) exemplify this challenge.

Nemertean worms are found in most benthic marine habitats, where they play important roles as predators. Some are of significance to fisheries, as parasites or predators of commercially important species (e.g., crabs, lobsters, clams, and glass eels). Nemertean toxins, used by these worms to subdue their prey and deter predators, have biomedical potential, and some have been investigated for use in treating such conditions as Alzheimer's disease and schizophrenia. Despite their importance, nemerteans remain among the lesser-known marine phyla. About 1400 species are described worldwide, but recent sampling efforts, including those supported by this award, show that this represents only a small fraction of the actual diversity.

As one of the few world experts on nemerteans, PI Maslakova’s goals in this collaborative project were to 1) advance taxonomic research on nemerteans, 2) create resources to improve taxonomic access, and 3) train new experts in taxonomy and systematics of this understudied phylum of marine invertebrates.

Supported by this award, Maslakova recruited and trained a new Ph.D. student in nemertean systematics, taught an immersive two-week course on nemertean taxonomy at the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute’s field station in Bocas del Toro, Panama, and engaged dozens of undergraduate students in research on nemertean diversity of the Caribbean and Pacific coasts of Panama. To support the training of new experts, Maslakova and her Ph.D. trainee developed an informal illustrated identification guide to the nemerteans of the Caribbean.

To improve taxonomic access for non-specialists, Maslakova collaborated with a professional videographer to create a series of educational videos on nemertean systematics and species identification. These videos are made publicly available on YouTube, and used by educators, researchers of marine biodiversity, and nemertean taxonomists-in-training.

The research supported by this award has been disseminated in the form of peer-reviewed publications (Maslakova et al. 2022, Cherneva et al. 2023, and Ellison et al. 2024), presentations at national conferences, lectures, and invited talks, and some received broad coverage by the media. At least two other major manuscripts documenting the nemertean diversity of Panama are in preparation and constitute the core of a Ph.D. dissertation in progress.

This research revealed a large amount of new nemertean diversity of the Caribbean (213 species compared to 60 previously reported) and Pacific coasts of Panama (91 species compared to 10 previously reported). Most of these species are undescribed. Most were also revealed to have look-alikes, highlighting the importance of DNA barcoding for identification and new species descriptions. A significant fraction of these species was only found in their planktonic larval form, which underscores the importance of sampling multiple life stages for improved estimates of biodiversity (Maslakova et al. 2022). While we described a few of the newly discovered species in the context of taxonomic revisionary studies (Cherneva et al. 2023), and several dozen descriptions are in progress, many species cannot be formally described because we lack information on adult morphology or cannot place them within well-circumscribed genera. This highlights the need for systematic revisions of the phylum, based on phylogenetic analyses, which are outside the scope of this grant.

Finally, this award supported a large sampling effort (>1300 specimens) of nemerteans in the Southwest Caribbean and Panama Bight marine ecoregions. Morphological vouchers, tissue samples for DNA barcoding, and associated metadata have been deposited with the Museo de Biología Marina y Limnología (University of Panama) and the Smithsonian Institution’s National Museum of Natural History (under appropriate Material Transfer Agreement with Panama). DNA sequence data produced with this funding has been deposited into public databases (National Center for Biotechnology Information’s GenBank and Barcode of Life Datasystems).
